name: Elisabeth Opsahl
skills: ['English', 'Music', 'Classical', 'Coaching', 'Teaching', 'Early Music', 'Dutch', 'Chamber Music']
summary:
Elisabeth Opsahl studied RECORDER at the Norwegian State Academy of Music (Oslo, Norway) and at the Royal Conservatory of the Hague and the Hogeschool voor de Kunsten Utrecht in the Netherlands. Her teachers were, amongst others, R-M Verhagen and H ter Schegget. She specialized in music from the baroque era, but she also worked with contemporary music, often in cooperation with composers.

She studied CORNETTO at the Conservatoire de Musique de Geneve (Geneve, Switserland) and at the Schola Cantorum Basiliensis (Basel, Switserland). Her teachers were William Dongois and Bruce Dickey. During her cornetto studies, she focused on the styles and historical performance practice of music from the 16th and 17th century, with improvisation as a main field.

She performed with various ensembles in the Netherlands, Belgium and Norway (a.o. Brabants Musyccollegium, Il Concerto Barocco, Holland Opera, Oslo Baroque Orchestra, Barokkanerne).
She also gave concerts in the United States, Israel, Finland and Australia, with orchestras as the Finnish Baroque Orchestra and Jerusalem BaroqueOrchestra.

Elisabeth works regularly with project orchestras and smaller chamber music ensembles. She is a member of the ensembles “Breeze recorder consort”,  “the Delta Consort” (woodwind and brass, strings and continuo instruments) and ”Ensemble Noorderlicht” (an ensemble that mainly works with Scandinavian music).

Elisabeth also participated in music theater productions. She has written and arranged scripts and music for performances.

Elisabeth conducts the Nordic Choir Rotterdam and Grov Skole- og amatørkorps.
She gives lectures and workshops about various aspects of music and culture.

In addition to her musical work, Elisabeth owns and runs the Scandinavian language school ”ScandiTaal – Centrum voor Scandinavische Talen en Cultuur” and “Linguanor - Norwegian language course”. The schools offerlanguage courses on a high level to companies, groups and individuals.

Elisabeth lives partly in The Hague, Netherlands and in Grovfjord, Norway.

name: Noortje van Amsterdam
skills: ['Qualitative Research', 'Sociology', 'Anthropology', 'Ethnography', 'Social Research', 'Research', 'Teaching', 'Gender', 'Lecturing', 'Social Sciences', 'Political Science', 'Cultural Anthropology', 'Report Writing', 'Politics', 'Theory', 'SPSS', 'Quantitative Research']
summary:
Noortje van Amsterdam is assistant professor Organization Studies at Utrecht School of Governance. Her research focusses on the social constructions and performances of bodies and health. Informed by feminist poststructuralism, intersectionality, postcolonial theories and new materialism, she aims to explore the ideological power structures and material circumstances that shape inequalities based on embodied signifiers such as gender, dis/ability, age, sexuality and race/ethnicity. In her research, she combines conventional qualitative methodologies with Arts-Based Research (e.g. poetic inquiry, visual methods, autoethnographic writing) to shed light on the everyday experiences of people with (their) bodies and health and to inspire critical reflexivity and empathic understanding. On the website she has created with Dide van Eck - www.poetryatwork.me - you can find some of her research poetry.

Noortje has explored the constructions and performances of bodies and health in different settings such as professional organizations, academia, physical education, and dance. Themes she addresses in her research include: fatness, dis/ability, motherhood, menopause, diversity in education, and young people's identities. The interdisciplinary nature of her research brings together organization studies, gender studies, health sociology, education, disability studies, fat studies and sport sociology.

Keywords:  embodiment, diversity, health, gender, age, disability, fatness, discourse, qualitative research, arts-based methodologies.

name: Astrid Surmatz
position 1: Member of Linnaeus University Centre for Concurrences in Colonial and Postcolonial Studies
skills: ['Literature', 'Research', 'Arctic', 'Academic Writing', 'Translation', 'Higher Education', 'International Education', 'Social Sciences', 'History', 'Editing', 'International Relations', 'Linguistics', 'Political Science', 'Pedagogy', 'Science', 'E-Learning', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Literature Reviews', 'Multilingual', 'Scientific Writing']
summary:
In recent years my research has focussed on intermedial representations of the subarctic and polar areas. I am a tenured Assistant professor at Amsterdam university, and I am also a member of the Concurrences LNUC research group in Sweden, where I was named Associate professor in 2013. Due to my research on Linnaeus, I was elected Fellow of the Linnean Society, FLS. In Amsterdam, I continue to be a member of the European Travel Cluster, of the Digitial Emotions Group and of the Translation studies Group and am a member of the VOSSIUS institute for the history of science. I served as a Board member of the IRSCL from 2011-2015 and of the APECS council 2013-2016, and am a member of HASSEG and PEI. Also, I have published and co-edited several volumes on Children´s literature, postcolonial studies and on Astrid Lindgren. I am a member of several editorial boards and co-editor of a bookseries at Winter.
After finishing my PhD in Scandinavian Studies and English literature, I worked first as a lecturer in Göttingen, participating in several larger research projects on translation studies and international relations. Then I moved on to the Scandinavian department at the University of Cologne as an Assistant professor and then further to the Scandinavian department at Amsterdam University as an Assistant professor where I received tenure after two years. During five years, I was first Astrid Lindgren Memorial professor and later Visiting professor at Linnaeus University in Comparative literature and Literary studies.
